body_content.explanation: used when the subject of the verb is "I" and the object is the same person:
examples: I bought myself a new coat.
I caught sight of myself in the mirror.
Yes, I thought to myself, it's time to take a holiday.

body_content.explanation: used to emphasize "I" as the subject of a sentence:
examples: I myself don't like a heavy meal at lunchtime.
I don't like a heavy meal at lunchtime myself.
My husband and myself were delighted with the gift.
They very kindly invited my sister and myself to the inauguration.

body_content.explanation: alone or without help from anyone else:
examples: I live by myself .
I had to do the whole job all by myself .
I'm ashamed to say I ate the whole plateful all by myself.
Are you going to leave me all by myself?
I don't especially like travelling by myself.
I managed to take a shower by myself for the first time since the operation.
I can't move all those boxes by myself.
I never get an hour to myself.
I had a couple of hours to myself between appointments so I thought I'd visit the cathedral.
I usually get an hour or so to myself before the rest of the family get up and I love it.
I had a double room all to myself and it was wonderful.
For half an hour I had the whole pool to myself.
So I get to have you all to myself this evening, do I?

body_content.explanation: not to be or feel as happy or as healthy as usual:
examples: I'm sure you're aware that I haven't been myself lately.
I went to see the doctor because I haven't been quite myself lately.
I'm normally pretty upbeat but I really haven't felt myself since the news.
I don't know how else to put it except that I haven't been feeling like myself.
Since the accident I haven't felt myself.
I thought I was doing better, but I still don't quite feel like myself yet.

body_content.explanation: used when describing your state of mind when you are physically ill:
examples: I'm well enough in myself (= happy) - I've just got this nagging headache.
